Introduction

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a rare primary immunodeficiency disorder of phagocytic metabolism characterized by phagocytes (eg, neutrophils) with impaired NADPH oxidase activity.  Patients are at risk for severe, recurrent bacterial and fungal infections and granuloma formation.

Pathogenesis



CGD most commonly occurs due to an X-linked recessive mutation in the gene that encodes NADPH oxidase, a membrane-bound enzyme complex that catalyzes the reduction of oxygen to reactive oxygen species (ROS) (eg, superoxide, hydrogen peroxide) during the respiratory burst (

figure 1
).  ROS activate granule proteases that kill phagocytosed pathogens within the phagolysosome.



Without NADPH oxidase, patients with CGD have an impaired respiratory burst.  Although protease degranulation occurs normally, these proteases are not activated due to the absence of ROS, resulting in defective phagocytic intracellular killing.  The defective phagocytes in patients with CGD can still kill many pathogens because most microorganisms naturally produce hydrogen peroxide as a byproduct of metabolism, which can activate granule proteases.  However, catalase-positive bacteria and fungi are pathogenic in CGD because they degrade their own metabolically produced hydrogen peroxide (an ROS), further limiting microbicidal protease activation.  Therefore, patients with CGD are susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms, particularly:



  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Burkholderia cepacia
  • Serratia marcescens
  • Nocardia
  • Aspergillus fumigatus


In addition, in CGD phagocytes can migrate to infection sites but are unable to degrade inflammatory signals and invading pathogens; this leads to a chronic and focal aggregation of inflammatory cells, known as granulomas.  Therefore, the pathological hallmark of CGD is diffuse granuloma formation, particularly in the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts.

Clinical presentation



Patients typically present with severe, recurrent bacterial and fungal infections with catalase-positive organisms in infancy and early childhood.  Of note, immune response to viral infections remains intact.  The most common sites of infection include the following:



  • Lungs (eg, pneumonia)
  • Skin (eg, cellulitis)
  • Lymph nodes (eg, suppurative adenitis)
  • Liver (eg, abscess)


In addition, patients often develop granulomas in the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts due to chronic activation of inflammatory cytokines.  These can result in the clinical manifestations of colitis, stricture and/or fistulae formation, and obstruction.  In addition, patients may have growth failure and poor wound healing.

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected CGD (eg, recurrent or severe infections with catalase-positive pathogens in children), neutrophil-function testing should be performed, which includes:



  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry:  detects the generation of oxygen free radicals by measuring the oxidation of DHR to rhodamine, a fluorescent green compound that can be detected on flow cytometry.  There is reduced or absent fluorescence (
    figure 2
    ) in patients with CGD.
  • Nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test:  less sensitive than DHR flow cytometry.  In the presence of NBT, functional neutrophils produce ROS, thereby converting pale blue nitroblue tetrazolium to dark blue formazan that precipitates within the cells.  There is no change in color in patients with CGD.


If either test of neutrophil function is positive, then genetic testing should be performed to identify the underlying genetic mutation.  In general, B- and T-cell concentrations are normal, and leukocyte count may be normal or elevated (eg, during acute infection).  In addition, quantitative immunoglobulin analysis is normal.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for CGD includes other primary immunodeficiencies (

) and conditions that cause recurrent or severe infections or granulomas.  Laboratory evaluation (eg, leukocyte count, quantitative immunoglobulin analysis) often distinguish CGD from the following diagnoses:



  • Cystic fibrosis:  This disorder can present with recurrent respiratory infections and granuloma formation in the lungs.  However, extrapulmonary infections (eg, in the skin or liver) are not expected.
  • Hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome:  As in CGD, patients are prone to staphylococcal infections and Aspergillus infections in the lungs.  However, patients have characteristic facies and elevated serum IgE, which are not features of CGD.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency:  This condition leads to recurrent infections and variable impairment of the oxidative burst.  G6PD deficiency is characterized by hemolytic anemia, unlike in CGD.

Management



Management of CGD involves antimicrobial prophylaxis as well as prompt diagnosis and treatment of active infections.



  • Antimicrobial prophylaxis most commonly includes trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole to prevent bacterial infections and itraconazole to prevent fungal infections, particularly Aspergillus infections.
  • When acute infection is suspected, the infected tissue should be sent for culture, immediately followed by administration of broad-spectrum, empiric antibacterial and antifungal (eg, voriconazole, amphotericin B) therapies.  The antibiotic regimen should be adjusted according to culture results, but in general infections require prolonged courses of antibiotics.


Obstructive granulomas or abscesses may require surgical resection or drainage, respectively.



Hematopoietic stem cell transplant is curative but reserved for severe cases only, given the risk of life-threatening complications.

Prognosis



The prognosis of CGD has improved significantly with antimicrobial prophylaxis.  Nevertheless, Aspergillus is the leading cause of death in patients with CGD and is typically acquired via inhalation of spores found in the soil.  In general, patients with severe disease are at the highest risk for morbidity and mortality, including granulomatous complications.  Granulomatous inflammation can lead to gastrointestinal and genitourinary tract obstruction, requiring prompt surgical intervention.



In addition, patients are at increased risk for autoimmune diseases (likely due to an impaired ability to degrade inflammatory cytokines) like inflammatory bowel disease and lupus-like syndrome.

Summary



Chronic granulomatous disease (
